 You ignore the fact that we've totally destroyed Iraq's infrastructure, subjected the civilian population to conditions far below their prior standard of living and created circumstances leading to what is as close to civil war as they can be without an official announcement. All in a country with no former ties to al Quaeda. It doesn't get much dumber than that. 
 
 With the exception of those countries who joined the US in destroying Iraq and supporting Israeli real estate policies, no other nation has policies that oppress the ME or invite retaliation. That reflects intelligent foreign policy, not cowardliness.
 
 If you believe domination of Iraq is going to limit extremist retaliation towards US ME policy you're badly fooling yourself. We're doing more damage to ourselves there than anything extremists could ever hope to mount on their own. If that's what you consider safety, then you should examine your motives. 
 
 Current administration will bear the poor legacy of our Iraq folly, regardless of the final outcome.

He appreciates the absence of Hussien and that he voted for the existing government. A government who was not President Bush's hoped for leadership. Freedom is not easy. That in itself presents you as pathetic.

 
 I don't recall personally attacking you, is this post a sample of your personal manners or frustrated support of current administration? 
 
 No one has to discredit current administration; they've done that to themselves with gross fiscal irresponsibility, self-serving ties to industry, removal of civil rights, ignoring our laws and the Iraq fiasco. If you're unaware of their shortcomings you must be on a different planet. I certainly wouldn't waste the effort to hate any politician for any reason. 
 
 One of our cleaning ladies has a son in the army stationed in Iraq, 2nd time, a lifer, who says we shouldn't be there. Another friend has a son in the marines who emails him and his wife, says we're stupid for being there and that the country is a real mess with extreme hatred of all Americans. I guess it depends on who one talks to about Iraq. I personally prefer information from analytical sources on a larger scope with no personal involvement to avoid emotional distortion on any subject. 
 
 You seem very emotional about our mess in Iraq. Perhaps that's the reason any critique of current administration upsets you and you feel justified in making personal attacks. If you can ever resist using left and right to form your opinions that anger would probably disappear. 
 
 Bye bye.
gman

I don't recall personally attacking you, is this post a sample of your personal manners or frustrated support of current administration? 
 
 No one has to discredit current administration; they've done that to themselves with gross fiscal irresponsibility, self-serving ties to industry, removal of civil rights, ignoring our laws and the Iraq fiasco. If you're unaware of their shortcomings you must be on a different planet. I certainly wouldn't waste the effort to hate any politician for any reason. 
 
 One of our cleaning ladies has a son in the army stationed in Iraq, 2nd time, a lifer, who says we shouldn't be there. Another friend has a son in the marines who emails him and his wife, says we're stupid for being there and that the country is a real mess with extreme hatred of all Americans. I guess it depends on who one talks to about Iraq. I personally prefer information from analytical sources on a larger scope with no personal involvement to avoid emotional distortion on any subject. 
 
 You seem very emotional about our mess in Iraq. Perhaps that's the reason any critique of current administration upsets you and you feel justified in making personal attacks. If you can ever resist using left and right to form your opinions that anger would probably disappear. 
 
 Bye bye.

 
 I did not suggest a personal attack on myself. I said your response to any who disagree consist of degrading comments and always ends in a dismissal with an upturn and a twist of a snooty nose. 
 I don't have conversations with my wife's sister about the conditions in Iraq.
 I speak to her son and her daughter-in-law. Mom is safe at home. Like the people who are providing you their analysis. My Iraq friend who is a medical student "lives" and functions within what he defines as a better Iraq.
 I have offered to help he and his family to stay with us and he states that Iraq will not get better if the proponents of Democracy leave. 
 My defense of the actions which will help Iraqis experience democracy have little to do with fervor of "current admin" as you refer to the President, (based, I suspect on some childish vow not to speak the name). It has to do with recognizing Iraqis as humans worthy of the effort.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Details of the nice trip from America to Iraq
